title: Waiver Request Undergoing CMS Review
first_heading: State of Alabama Medicaid Workforce Initiative

faqs.description: Waiver request submitted to CMS on 6/29/2018; revised waiver requests submitted to CMS on 7/31/2018 and 9/10/2018

FFS

  • Parents and caretakers with incomes from 0-18% FPL
No
• State plan cost-sharing
No
No
No

• Requests ability to condition Medicaid eligibility for non-disabled adults ages 19-59 on work/CE requirements
  • Individuals subject to work/CE requirements must participate in community engagement activities (e.g., employment, on-the-job training, job search and job-readiness activities, education, volunteering, or technical training); number of hours required varies based on the age of their dependent children: 20 hours/week for individuals with dependent children under age six and 35 hours/week for all other individuals subject to the requirement
  • Proposed exempt populations include: individuals with a disability (includes individuals receiving SSI or SSDI), medically frail individuals, individuals with a medical condition that prevents them from complying with work/CE requirements, pregnant women, women who recently gave birth, individuals required to care for a disabled child or adult, individuals participating in active SUD treatment, individuals enrolled in and compliant or exempt from TANF work requirements (includes individuals who meet a good cause exemption under TANF), parents or caretakers of a child age 12 months or younger, parents and caretakers of a child under age six for whom childcare is not available
  • Individuals who do not comply with work/CE requirements or demonstrate proof of an exemption within 90 days of becoming subject to the work requirement are dis-enrolled
  • After initial 90-day period, individuals must comply with the work requirement each month; individuals who fail to comply with work/CE requirements in a given month are dis-enrolled after a 30-day grace period
  • Individuals whose incomes increase above Medicaid limits are eligible for 18 months of TMA

title: Approved through 9/2021
first_heading: Arizona Health Care Cost Containment System (AHCCCS)

faqs.description:
• Waiver extension approved on 9/30/2016; effective 10/1/2016 to 9/30/2021
  • Waiver amendment approved on 1/18/2019
faqs.description2: Waiver amendment request submitted to CMS on 12/19/2017; second amendment request for waiver of retroactive coverage submitted to CMS on 4/6/2018

faqs.description:
MMC

  • Nearly all Medicaid enrollees with limited exceptions
  • AHCCCS CARE Accounts (similar to an HSA) funded by enrollee and/or third-party contributions
faqs.description2:
MMC

  • New proposed waiver features apply to expansion adults with incomes from 0-138%

faqs.description:
• For expansion adults with incomes >100% FPL (medically frail individuals, individuals with a SMI, and American Indians/Alaska Natives are exempt)
  • Lesser of 2% of income or $25
  • In the form of a contribution to AHCCCS Care Account
  • Individuals who fail to pay premiums within a two-month grace period dis-enrolled; may reenroll at any time and do not have to pay back premiums
  • Individuals may request a hardship exemption if a household member dies or household has qualifying expenses >10% of household income during the previous month
  • Only individuals making timely premium payments may access AHCCCS CARE Account funds

• For expansion adults with incomes > 100% FPL (medically frail individuals, individuals with a SMI, and American Indians/Alaska Natives are exempt)
  • Co-payments up to 3% of income
  • Co-payments limited to non-emergency use of the ER, opioids, specialist services without PCP referral, and brand name drugs when a generic is available
  • Co-payments charged on a retrospective basis
  • Only individuals making timely co-payments may access AHCCCS CARE Account funds

• May eliminate premiums and cost-sharing obligations for six months
  • May enable access to AHCCCS CARE Account funds
  • May enable individuals to rollover AHCCCS CARE Account funds
• Requests waiver of the IMD exclusion for individuals receiving mental health and SUD services regardless of length of stay (as part of separate waiver amendment application)
faqs.description2: • Requests waiver of the IMD exclusion for individuals receiving mental health and SUD services regardless of length of stay (as part of separate waiver amendment application)

faqs.description: • Retroactive coverage waived (pregnant women, women ≤60 days postpartum, and children < age 19 exempt)
faqs.description2:
• Requests waiver of retroactive coverage
  • Requests five-year lifetime Medicaid enrollment limit for individuals subject to work/CE requirements; months that an individual complies with work requirement or 5 is exempt do not count towards limit
  • Proposes twice annual redeterminations for individuals subject to work/CE requirements

faqs.description:
• Conditions Medicaid eligibility for adults ages 19-49 on work/CE requirements
  • Individuals subject to work/CE requirements must participate in ≥80 hours/month of employment or education activities (e.g., employment, job search activities, education, life skills training, health education classes, community services, etc.); individuals transitioning from the justice system, living in areas with high-unemployment, or facing barriers to finding work may participate in community service to meet requirement
  • Exempt populations include: members of federal recognized tribes, pregnant women, women ≤60 days postpartum, former foster care children under age 26, individuals with SMI, individuals receiving temporary or permanent disability benefits, full-time students, victims of domestic violence, homeless individuals, parents or caregivers of a child under age 18 or who is 18 and a full-time student (limited to one exemption per household), caregivers of an individual with a disability, medically frail individuals, individuals in SUD treatment, individuals who are unable to work because of a physical or behavioral health condition, individuals with a disability, individuals receiving SNAP, TANF, or unemployment insurance, and individuals participating in other AHCCCS-approved work programs
  • Individuals have three-month grace period prior to being required to comply with work/CE requirements; after three-month grace period, individuals who fail to comply with requirements have their benefits suspended for two months; state will automatically reactivate coverage at end of two-month period
  • Individuals may re-activate suspended coverage early by meeting a “good cause” exemption (e.g., disability, illness, illness of household member, severe inclement weather, or family emergency), qualifying for an exemption, or becoming eligible for an eligibility group not subject to work/CE requirements
faqs.description2:
• Requests ability to condition Medicaid eligibility for adults ages 19-54 on work/CE requirements
  • Individuals subject to work/CE requirements must participate in ≥20 hours/week of employment or education activities (e.g.,employment, job-search activities, education, or participation in Employment Support and Development courses); individuals transitioning from the justice system, living in areas with high-unemployment, or facing barriers to finding work may participate in community service to meet requirement
  • Proposed exempt populations include: American Indians, women who recently gave birth, former foster care children under age 26, individuals with SMI, individuals receiving temporary or permanent disability benefits, full time students, victims of domestic violence, homeless individuals, individuals recently impacted by a catastrophic event, parents or caregivers of a child under age 13, caregivers of a family member enrolled in the Arizona Long-Term Care System, and medically frail individuals
  • Individuals who initially fail to comply with work/CE requirements dis-enrolled after a 6- month grace period; may re-enroll upon meeting work/CE requirements for 30 consecutive days
  • Individuals who report a change in circumstances that results in non-compliance with work/CE requirements (e.g., job loss) or are determined non-compliant at redetermination will have 3-month grace period to comply prior to disenrollment; State proposes conducting redetermination at the end of the 3-month grace period
  • Requests expenditure authority for federal match for costs associated with the design, development, installation, operation, and administration of systems (both Medicaid and non-Medicaid) necessary to implement work/CE requirements
  • Requests ability to condition Medicaid eligibility on completion of Medicaid application questions on compliance with workrequirements and work requirements exemption criteria

faqs.description:
Yes (AHCCCS CARE Account)

  • Populations exempt from or not subject to premiums (e.g., expansion adults and parents/caretakers with incomes ≤100% FPL, pregnant women, individuals with an SMI, and American Indian/Alaska Natives) may opt-in to an AHCCCS CARE Account if it is funded by a third party or if they choose to pay premiums; if they opt in, they are not subject to penalties for failure to pay premiums or cost-sharing, and are not required to participate in healthy behaviors or continuously contribute to access AHCCCS Care Account funds

faqs.description2: Waiver Amendment Request; IMD Exclusion Waiver Amendment Request; Retroactive Coverage Waiver Amendment Request

faqs.description:
Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval in 2016:

Premiums and Cost-Sharing

  • Individuals with incomes ≤100% FPL subject to both premiums and co-payments
  • Six-month lockout period for individuals with incomes >100% who fail to make timely premium payments
  • Debt to the state for individuals with incomes ≤100% FPL who fail to make timely premium payments
  • Up to $25 co-payment for non-emergency ER visits
  • Liability for co-payments for services that would have been rendered at a missed appointment

Benefit and Eligibility Variations

  • Waiver of NEMT for individuals with incomes >100% FPL
  • Five-year lifetime Medicaid enrollment limit
  • Requirement to verify income on a monthly basis
  • One-year dis-enrollment for individuals who “knowingly” failed to report a change in income

Employment-Related Provisions

  • Requirement that individuals be employed, actively seeking employment, attending school, or participating in a job training program
  • One-year dis-enrollment of individuals who “knowingly” misreport adherence to work/CE requirements
  • Access to AHCCCS CARE Account funds conditioned on AHCCCS Works program participation

Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval in 2019:

Eligibility-Related Provisions

  • Five-year lifetime Medicaid enrollment limit for individuals subject to work/CE requirements

Work/CE Requirements

  • Expenditure authority for federal match for costs associated with the design, development, installation, operation, and administration of systems (both Medicaid and non-Medicaid) necessary to implement work/CE requirements
  • Ability to condition Medicaid eligibility on completion of Medicaid application questions on compliance with work requirements and work requirements exemption criteria
faqs.category_name: Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval

faqs.description:
• Waiver initially approved on 9/27/2013; effective 1/1/2014 to 12/31/2016
  • Waiver extension and amendment request approved on 12/8/2016; effective 1/1/2017 to 12/31/2021
  • Waiver amendment request approved on 3/5/2018

QHP Premium Assistance

  • Expansion adults with incomes from 0-138% FPL
  • Medically frail individuals are excluded

• For individuals with incomes >100% FPL
  • Up to 2% of income
  • Payment is not a condition of eligibility
  • Nonpayment results in debt to the state

• For individuals with incomes >100% FPL
  • Cost-sharing subject to maximum permitted Medicaid cost-sharing levels

• Individuals may receive incentive benefit for engaging with a PCP if authorized via a subsequent waiver amendment
  • Individuals with incomes >100% FPL must also make timely premium payments to be eligible for incentive benefit
• No coverage of non-emergency use of the ER for expansion adults
• Limited waiver of retroactive coverage; state must provide retroactive coverage for 30 days instead of three months

• Conditions Medicaid eligibility for adults ages 19-49 on work/CE requirements
  • Individuals subject to work/CE requirements must participate in ≥80 hours/month of work/CE activities (e.g., employment, job search and training activities, education, vocational training, community service or volunteering, health care-related classes, activities available through the Arkansas Department of Workforce Services, or employment activities available under SNAP or TANF); individuals must report on compliance via electronic portal
  • Exempt populations include pregnant women, women who recently gave birth, medically frail individuals, full-time students, individuals exempt from work/CE requirements in SNAP or TANF, individuals who receive TANF benefits, individuals with a short-term incapacitation, individuals who are medically certified as physically or mentally unable to work, individuals with an acute medical condition that prevents them from complying with the work requirement, individuals caring for an incapacitated person, individuals living with a minor dependent child under age 17, individuals receiving unemployment benefits, and individuals in active SUD treatment
  • Individuals who fail to comply with work/CE requirements for three consecutive or nonconsecutive months within a plan year are dis-enrolled; individuals may not re-enroll until start of next plan year unless they turn age 50, qualify for another Medicaid eligibility category, or would have qualified for a good cause exemption but could not report it due to a catastrophic event/circumstances beyond their control
  • Months in which an individual meets a good cause exemption (e.g., disability, hospitalization, hospitalization of household member, birth or death of a household member, severe inclement weather, or family emergency) do not count as a month of non-compliance
  • State must submit eligibility and enrollment monitoring plan to CMS within 90 days of waiver approval to “allow CMS to track Arkansas' compliance with the assurances described in the STCs, including several related to eligibility and application processing systems;” state may not dis-enroll any individuals for non-compliance with work requirement until CMS approves plan

Original Waiver Proposal; Waiver Extension Application; Waiver Amendment Request; Demonstration Approval

Partial Expansion

  • Reduction of eligibility level for expansion adults to 100% FPL, while continuing to receive the enhanced FMAP for expansion adults with incomes from 0-100% FPL (CMS was silent on this request when it approved work and community engagement requirements)

Benefit and Eligibility Variations

  • Request for waiver of requirement to provide retroactive coverage (state received limited waiver requiring it provide retroactive coverage for only 30 days instead of the three months required by Medicaid law)

Administrative Requirements

  • Request to eliminate requirements related to conducting administrative renewals in the event of a waiver phase-out

FFS

  • Parents and caretakers with incomes from 0-105% FPL

  • Individuals eligible for family planning services with incomes from 0-209% FPL
  • Reasonable classifications of individuals under age 21 with incomes from 0-156% FPL

  • Medically needy parents and caretakers with incomes from 0-100% FPL
  • Special benefits waiver (HIV) population with incomes from 0-250% FPL
  • Former foster care children up to age 26

• For individuals with incomes from ≥51% FPL

  • Individuals who fail to fail to pay premiums dis-enrolled with no grace period and are not permitted to re-enroll for 90-days unless they pay all past due premiums

• State plan cost-sharing
  • $10 co-pay for non-emergency ER visits

faqs.description:
FFS, MMC and/or ACO

  • Nearly all Medicaid enrollees with limited exceptions
  • Current mandatory MMC enrollees may choose to enroll in ACO and/or current MMC options

ESI and Student Health Insurance Premium Assistance

  • Mandatory for all Medicaid enrollees with access to cost-effective ESI or student health insurance
faqs.description2:
Same as the current waiver with the following changes:

  • Requests ability to limit income eligibility for expansion adults and non-disabled parents and caretaker relatives to 100% FPL while obtaining ACA’s enhanced match rate

  • Sliding scale based on income

• Adults subject to state plan cost-sharing

faqs.description2:
• Proposes tracking cost-sharing on annual instead of quarterly basis

faqs.description: No

faqs.description2:
Same as current waiver with the following additions and changes:

  • Requests ability to transition non-disabled parents and caretaker relatives ages 21-64 with incomes ≤100% FPL to ABP
  • Requests NEMT waiver for childless, non- pregnant and non-disabled individuals ages 21 to 64 with incomes from 0-138% FPL; waiver would not apply for transport to SUD services
  • Requests waiver of “all restrictions on payments to IMDs” for individuals receiving mental health and SUD services

faqs.description:
• 90-day retroactive coverage waived; most enrollees eligible for 10-day retroactive coverage
  • If state is unable to verify eligibility through electronic data sources and applicant information not reasonably compatible with electronic data, individuals eligible for 90-day provisional eligibility while state verifies applicant information
faqs.description2:
Same as current waiver with the following additions:

  • Seeks to eliminate emergency Medicaid for individuals eligible to purchase $0/month premium subsidized QHPs on the Marketplace regardless of length of stay
  • Requests ability to eliminate 90-day provisional eligibility when income cannot be verified for adults ages 21+ (pregnant women, HIV-positive adults with incomes <200% of the FPL, and individuals ages <65 with breast and cervical cancer and incomes <250% FPL would still be able to obtain 90-day provisional eligibility)

faqs.description: No

• 90-day retroactive coverage waived; most enrollees eligible for 10-day retroactive coverage
  • If state is unable to verify eligibility through electronic data sources and applicant information not reasonably compatible with electronic data, individuals eligible for 90-day provisional eligibility while state verifies applicant information

Same as current waiver with the following change:

  • Requests elimination of cost-sharing wrap for individuals enrolled in ESI or student health insurance premium assistance who receive care from a non-Medicaid participating provider

faqs.description: Yes
Original Waiver Application; Original Waiver Amendment Request; Second Waiver Amendment Request; Demonstration Approval

Partial Expansion

  • Reduction of eligibility level for expansion adults and non-disabled parents and caretaker relatives to 100% FPL, while continuing to receive the enhanced FMAP for expansion adults with incomes from 0-100% FPL (Neither approved nor denied)

Section 1927

  • Request to waive Section 1927 to obtain additional flexibility to exclude drugs from its formulary while continuing to receive rebates required by Medicaid law (CMS noted it would consider requests to waive Section 1927 if a state eliminated drug coverage under its State Plan and proposed to cover drugs through expenditure authority. In this scenario, a state would negotiate directly with drug companies and did not receive the rebates required by federal law)

Changes to Waiver of the IMD Exclusion

  • Request to waive “all restrictions on payments to IMDs” for individuals receiving mental health and SUD services (State can continue its waiver of the IMD exclusion for individuals receiving diversionary behavioral health services)
faqs.category_name: Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval

faqs.description:
• Waiver approved on 1/27/2015; effective 2/1/2015 to 1/31/2018
  • One-month waiver extension approved on 1/22/2018; effective 1/31/2018 to 2/28/2018
  • Waiver extension and amendment request approved on 2/1/2018; effective 2/1/2018 to 12/31/2020

High-Deductible MMC Plan With Health Savings-Like Account

  • Expansion adults with incomes from 0-138% FPL
  • Parents and caretakers
  • Parents and caretakers eligible for TMA
  • Pregnant women
  • Medically frail individuals are included
  • SUD waiver features apply to broader Medicaid population

• For individuals with incomes from 0-138% FPL
  • In the form of sliding scale contributions to the POWER account (similar to an HSA
  • Range from $1/month to $20/month based on an individual’s income; premiums are <2% of income, except for tobacco users
  • 50% premium surcharge for tobacco users (i.e., premiums range from $1.50 to $30/month); surcharge waived in first year of enrollment and eliminated if individuals notify State that they no longer use tobacco
  • Mandatory for individuals with incomes >100% FPL who are not medically frail or pregnant; individuals who fail to pay monthly contributions within 60-day grace period dis-enrolled and are not be permitted to re-enroll for 6 months
  • Optional for individuals with incomes ≤100% FPL; individuals who make contributions receive an enhanced benefit package

• Individuals with incomes ≤100% FPL who do not contribute to POWER account subject to maximum permitted Medicaid cost-sharing
  • Individuals with incomes >100% FPL subject to maximum permitted Medicaid cost-sharing for non-emergency use of the ER
May reduce or eliminate POWER account contributions

• Offers three benefit packages; access to each package subject to income, eligibility category, and contributions to POWER account
  • Waiver of NEMT
  • Waiver of the IMD exclusion for enrollees receiving SUD services regardless of length of stay

• Retroactive coverage waived
  • No prompt enrollment requirement; coverage begins the first day of month of first POWER account contribution or 60 days after POWER account invoice for individuals with income ≤100% FPL who do not make a POWER account contribution; individuals may make a $10 “fast track pre-payment” to gain coverage the first day of the month of their eligibility determination
  • Dis-enrolls individuals who do not complete annual redetermination process (STCs establish goal of State completing at least 75% of renewals ex parte); dis-enrolled individuals who do not submit paperwork within 90 days subject to three-month lockout after end of 90-day period; individuals can re-enroll early if they meet a “good cause” exception (e.g., hospitalization, disability, death or hospitalization of immediate family member, enrollment in or loss of private insurance coverage, domestic violence, relocation from another state, disaster); medically frail individuals, low-income parents and caretakers, pregnant women, and women ≤60 days postpartum exempt

• Conditions Medicaid eligibility for adults ages 19-59 on work/CE requirements (i.e., work, education, and other activities)
  • Individuals subject to community engagement requirements must participate in up to 20 hours/week (phased in from date of implementation) of activities over eight months of the eligibility period (e.g., subsidized or unsubsidized employment, participation in MCO employment activities, job search and training activities, education, vocational training, community service or volunteering, caregiving for a non-dependent relative or other person with chronic disabling health condition, compliance with or exemption from SNAP requirements, participation in tribal workforce program, etc.); compliance assessed annually
  • Exempt populations include: pregnant women, medically frail individuals, primary caregivers of a dependent child under school age or who is disabled, individuals with temporary illness or incapacitation, individuals in active SUD treatment, individuals who meet or are exempt from TANF requirements, homeless individuals, and individuals who were recently incarcerated
  • Individuals who fail to comply with requirements have their benefits suspended until their redetermination date; individuals who are not in compliance at their redetermination date have their coverage terminated
  • Individuals may re-activate suspended coverage by meeting requirements for one month, meeting an exemption, becoming eligible for a Medicaid eligibility group not subject to work/CE requirements, or meeting a good cause exemption (e.g., disability, hospitalization, hospitalization of household member, domestic violence)
Yes (POWER account)
No

Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval in 2015:

Premiums

  •  Indiana proposed somewhat higher premiums than approved

Benefit and Eligibility Variations

  • Waiver of requirement to provide EPSDT for 19- and 20-year olds
  • Six-month lockout for individuals who do not submit annual redetermination paperwork within specified timeframes

Employment-Related Provisions:

  • Referral to state Gateway to Work job search and job training program as a condition of Medicaid eligibility for unemployed individuals and those working <20 hours/week; individuals would be required to acknowledge referral on HIP application

Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval in 2018:

Cost-Sharing

  • Up to $25 co-payment for non-emergency use of the ER (authority not extended in waiver amendment and extension)
faqs.category_name: Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval

faqs.description:
• Waiver initially approved on 12/30/2013; effective 4/1/2014 to 12/31/2018
  • Waiver amendment request approved on 12/17/2015 to permit a choice of delivery systems—MMC or QHP premium assistance— for expansion adults with incomes >100% FPL beginning on 4/1/2018
  • Waiver extension and amendment request approved on 12/21/2018; effective 1/1/2019 to 12/31/2023; eliminated approval for QHP premium assistance1

MMC

  • Expansion adults with incomes 0-138% FPL
  • Medically frail individuals are included

• For individuals with incomes >100% FPL
  • Premium amount differs according to length of enrollment
    • Enrolled <48 cumulative months: Up to 2% of income
    • Enrolled ≥48 cumulative months: 5% of income
  • Penalty for failure to make timely premium payments according to length of enrollment
    • Enrolled <48 cumulative months: debt to the state
    • Enrolled ≥48 cumulative months: Individuals who fail to pay premiums after 60-day grace period are dis-enrolled; may reenroll upon paying past due premiums, becoming exempt from premiums, or becoming eligible for a eligibility group not subject to premiums
      • Individuals who meet a “good cause” exemption (e.g., hospitalization, incapacitation, hospitalization or death of a household member, birth of a household member, family emergency or life changing event (divorce, domestic violence), temporary illness or injury, eviction or homelessness, natural disaster) will not be disenrolled for failure to pay premiums
  • Medically frail individuals, pregnant women, American Indians/Alaska Natives, individuals aged 19-20, and individuals enrolled in the Flint 1115 demonstration are exempt from premiums

• For individuals with incomes 0-100% FPL
    • Up to 2% of income; billed quarterly based on average incurred copayments from prior 6- month period; first bill is 6 months after enrollment
  • For individuals with incomes >100% FPL; amount differs by length of enrollment
    • Enrolled <48 cumulative months: Up to 2% of income; billed quarterly based on average incurred copayments from prior 6-month period; first bill is 6 months after enrollment
    • Enrolled ≥48 cumulative months: No co-payments required

• For individuals with incomes 0-100% FPL
    • May reduce co-payments by 50% once co-payments reach 2% of income by participating in healthy behaviors
  • For individuals with incomes >100% FPL; healthy behavior incentives differ according to length of enrollment by participating in healthy behaviors
    • Enrolled <48 cumulative months: May reduce co-payments by 50% once co-payments reach 2% of income and may reduce premiums by 50%
    • Enrolled ≥48 cumulative months: No longer eligible for reductions in co-payments or premiums; individuals required to complete HRA annually or meet an annual healthy behavior as a condition of eligibility. Individuals who fail to complete HRA or meet a healthy behavior prior to redetermination are disenrolled; cannot re-enroll until they complete an HRA, become exempt from HRA/healthy behavior requirements, or become eligible for Medicaid under a different eligibility group not subject to HRA/healthy behavior requirements
      • Medically frail individuals, pregnant women, and individuals enrolled in the Flint 1115 demonstration are exempt from HRA and healthy behavior requirements
      • Individuals who meet a “good cause” exemption (e.g., hospitalization, incapacitation, hospitalization or death of a household member, birth of a household member, family emergency or life changing event (divorce, domestic violence), temporary illness or injury, eviction or homelessness, natural disaster) will not be disenrolled for failure to meet HRA/healthy behavior requirements
No
No

• Conditions Medicaid eligibility for non-disabled adults ages 19-62 on work/CE requirements
  • Individuals subject to community engagement requirements must participate in ≥80 hours/month of work/CE activities (e.g., paid or unpaid employment, education, job or vocational training, volunteering, participation in tribal employment program, SUD treatment, job search activities)
  • Exempt populations include: caregiver of a dependent family member under age six (limited to one exemption per household), individuals receiving temporary or permanent disability benefits, full-time students, pregnant women, caretakers of a disabled dependent determined by a licensed medical professional to need full-time care (limited to one exemption per household), caretakers of an incapacitated individual, medically frail individuals, individuals medically unable to work, individuals who were incarcerated within the last 6 months, individuals receiving unemployment benefits, individuals who are disabled, former foster care youth under age 21, and individuals compliant with or exempt from SNAP or TANF work requirements
  • Individuals who fail to comply with work/CE requirements for 3 consecutive or nonconsecutive months within a 12-month reporting period are dis-enrolled; may re-enroll after one month upon meeting work/CE requirements, meeting a good cause exemption, or qualifying for an exemption
Yes (MI Health Account)
No
Original Waiver Application; Waiver Amendment Request; Waiver Extension Request; Amendment to Waiver Extension Request; Demonstration Approval

Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval in 2015:

Premiums and Cost-Sharing

  • Premiums of up to 3.5% of income for individuals >100% FPL enrolled in MMC
  • Cost-sharing cap of 7% of income for individuals >100% FPL enrolled in MMC

Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval in 2018:

Work/CE Requirements

  • Individuals who misrepresent their compliance with work/CE requirements would be disenrolled and not permitted to re-enroll for one year
faqs.category_name: Features from Waiver Application Not Included in Final Waiver Approval

faqs.description:
• Waiver initially approved on 12/10/2013; effective 1/1/2014 to 12/31/2016
  • Waiver extension request approved on 11/23/2016; effective 1/1/2017 to 12/31/2019
  • Waiver amendment request approved on 10/27/2017

MMC1 

  •  Expansion adults with incomes from 0-138% FPL
  •  Medically frail individuals are included

ESI Premium Assistance

  • Voluntary for expansion adults with incomes from 0-138% FPL

• For individuals with incomes >50% FPL beginning in second year of enrollment in demonstration (medically frail individuals exempt)
  • Up to $5/month for individuals with incomes from 50-100% FPL; up to $10/month for individuals with incomes from 100-138% FPL

• Conditions Medicaid eligibility for adults ages 19-64 on work/CE requirements
  • Individuals subject to work/CE requirements must participate ≥100 hours of work/CE activities per month (e.g., employment, job search and training activities, education); individuals must either report compliance or exemption or verify state data sources on compliance or exemption on a monthly basis
  • Exempt populations include individuals who: are temporarily incapacitated; are participating in a state-certified drug court program; are parent/caretaker of a child under age 6 or a child with disabilities (limited to one parent/caretaker per household); are parent/caretaker of a dependent where care is determined necessary by a provider; are pregnant or 60 days postpartum; are medically frail; are disabled and cannot comply because of disability related reasons; have a family member with a disability and cannot comply because of that disability; experience a hospitalization or serious illness or have a family member with a hospitalization or serious illness; and are exempt from SNAP/TANF work/CE requirements
  • Individuals who fail to comply with work/CE requirements have their benefits suspended after one-month grace period; coverage will not be suspended for individuals who meet an exemption or “good cause” exception (e.g., disability, birth or death of a household member, severe inclement weather, family emergency, inability to secure necessary childcare for a dependent child age 6-12) prior to the end of the one-month grace period or if they complete missed hours
  • Individuals may re-activate suspended coverage by completing missed hours, meeting the requirement for one month, meeting a standard or good cause exemption, or becoming eligible for a Medicaid eligibility group not subject to work/CE requirements
  • Individuals who are not in compliance at their redetermination date have their coverage terminated

title: Approved through 9/2023
first_heading: Kentucky Helping to Engage and Achieve Long Term Health (KY HEALTH)

faqs.description:
• Waiver re-approved on 11/20/2018; effective 11/20/2018 to 9/30/2023
  • Waiver originally approved on 1/12/2018; U.S. District Court invalidated CMS’s original approval on 6/29/2018 for failing to consider how the waiver furthered the objectives of the Medicaid program and remanded the waiver back to CMS for additional review; waiver application, amendment application, and STCs completed additional public comment period on 8/18/2018

High-Deductible MMC Plan with Health Savings-Like Account

  • Expansion adults with incomes from 0-138% FPL
  • Parents and caretakers
  • Individuals eligible for TMA
  • Pregnant women with incomes from 0-195% FPL
  • Former foster care youth up to age 26
  • Medically frail individuals are included
  • My Rewards Account (similar to an HSA) funded by Medicaid; individuals may earn funds by avoiding non-emergency ED visits, completing healthy behaviors, or exceeding work/CE requirements; may be used for additional benefits (e.g., vision or dental services, over-thecounter medications, gym memberships)
  • Deductible Account funded $1000 annually by Medicaid
  • Limited number of waiver features apply to broader Medicaid population (e.g., waiver of the IMD exclusion)

• Premiums charged at the household level instead of on a per-person basis if all household members subject to premiums are enrolled in the same MMC plan
  • For households with incomes from 0-138% FPL (medically frail individuals, former foster care youth, survivors of domestic violence, TMA enrollees and pregnant women exempt)
  • Range from $1/month to 4% of household income if all household members are enrolled in the same MMC plan; premiums may exceed 4% of household income if charged on a perperson basis (i.e. household members are not enrolled in the same plan)
  • Premium amounts may vary based on income or Medicaid enrollment duration
  • Premiums are mandatory for households with incomes >100% FPL; households that fail to pay premiums within 60-day grace period will be dis-enrolled and will not be permitted to reenroll for six months unless they pay up to two months of back premiums plus the next month’s premium (i.e. up to three months premium in total) and complete a health or financial literacy course, or meet a “good cause” exception (e.g., hospitalization, disability, death of immediate family member, eviction or homelessness, national disaster)
  • Premiums are optional for households with incomes ≤100% FPL; households that fail to pay premiums subject to state plan-level co-payments and lose access to My Rewards Account for six months unless they pay up to two months of back premiums plus the next month’s premium (i.e. up to three months premium in total) and complete a health or financial literacy course, or meet a “good cause” exception (e.g., hospitalization, disability, death of immediate family member, eviction or homelessness, national disaster)

• Individuals with incomes ≤100% FPL that do not pay premiums are subject to state plan costsharing (medically frail individuals, former foster care youth, survivors of domestic violence, and pregnant women exempt)
  • Households that reach the 5% quarterly cap on cost-sharing are required to pay $1/month premiums until end of quarter
•  Enrollees may accumulate My Rewards Account funds for completing healthy behaviors

• Waiver of NEMT for expansion adults
  • Waiver of NEMT for all Medicaid enrollees traveling to methadone treatment (medically frail individuals, former foster care youth, survivors of domestic violence, pregnant women, and individuals subject to EPSDT exempt)
  • Waiver of the IMD exclusion for all Medicaid enrollees receiving SUD services regardless of length of stay

• Waiver of retroactive coverage (former foster care youth and pregnant women exempt)
  • Waiver of prompt enrollment; coverage begins the first day of month of first premium payment or 60 days after premium invoice for individuals with income ≤100% FPL who do not make a premium payment (medically frail individuals, former foster care youth, survivors of domestic violence, pregnant women, and individuals found presumptively eligible exempt; effective eligibility date for TMA enrollees defined in state plan)
  • Individuals may pre-pay initial premium amount at application to expedite the start of coverage
  • Dis-enrolls individuals who do not complete annual redetermination process (State required to complete at least 75% of renewals ex parte); dis-enrolled individuals who do not submit paperwork within 90 days subject to six-month lockout; individuals can re-enroll early if they pay one month’s premium and complete a financial or health literacy course, or meet a “good cause” exception (e.g., hospitalization, disability, death of immediate family member, enrollment in or loss of private insurance coverage during determination reporting period, eviction or homelessness, national disaster); medically frail individuals, former foster care youth, survivors of domestic violence, and pregnant women exempt
  • Individuals who fail to report a change in circumstance that would lead to loss of Medicaid eligibility are dis-enrolled and will not be permitted to re-enroll for six months; individuals can re-enroll early if they pay one month’s premium and complete a financial or health literacy course, or meet a “good cause” exception (e.g., hospitalization, disability, death of immediate family member, enrollment in or loss of private insurance coverage during determination reporting period, eviction or homelessness, national disaster); medically frail individuals, former foster care youth, survivors of domestic violence, and pregnant women exempt

• Conditions Medicaid eligibility for adults ages 19-64 on work/CE requirements (i.e., work, education, and other activities)
  • Individuals subject to community engagement requirements must participate in ≥80 hours/month of work/CE activities (e.g., employment, job search and training activities, education, community service, compliance with SNAP and TANF work requirements, and SUD treatment)
  • Exempt populations include: pregnant women, former foster care youth, survivors of domestic violence, medically frail individuals, primary caregivers of a dependent including a disabled adult dependent (limited to one exemption per household), individuals with an acute medical conditions, and full-time students
  • Individuals who fail to comply with requirements have their benefits suspended after onemonth grace period; coverage will not be suspended for individuals who meet a “good cause” exception (e.g., disability, birth or death of a household member, severe inclement weather, family emergency) at least 10 days prior to the end of the one-month grace period
  • Individuals may re-activate their suspended coverage by meeting requirements for one month, completing a health or financial literacy course (limited to one course per 12-month period), meeting an exemption, or becoming eligible for a Medicaid eligibility group not subject to work/CE requirements

Yes (My Rewards Account)

  • State has authority to deduct from My Rewards Account for each non-emergency ER visit

Yes

  • Aligns individuals’ Medicaid annual renewal dates with their open enrollment date for ESI

• For individuals with incomes >100% FPL eligible for TMA (permitted until 12/31/2018):

Failure to complete drug screening, drug test, or SUD treatment would result in dis-enrollment; individuals required to consent to drug treatment before re-enrolling. Individuals who indicate willingness to obtain SUD treatment not required to complete drug screening as a condition of eligibility

faqs.description:
• Conditions Medicaid eligibility for childless adults ages 19-49 on work/CE requirements
  • Individuals subject to community engagement requirements must participate in >80 hours/month (e.g., subsidized or unsubsidized employment; participation in SNAP work requirements; participation in refugee employment and training program; participation in tribal work programs; or other state-approved work, job search, or job training activities)
  • Exempt populations include: individuals who are unable to work or participate in workforce training activities (e.g., individuals receiving SSI or SSDI, individuals mentally or physically unable to work as verified by state or healthcare professional, individuals experiencing chronic homelessness), primary caregivers of individuals who cannot care for themselves,individuals who are receiving or have applied for unemployment, individuals exempt from SNAP work requirements, individuals participating in a drug or alcohol treatment program, students enrolled at least half-time
  • Individuals who fail to comply for 48 months (consecutive or non-consecutive) will be disenrolled and not permitted to re-enroll for six months unless eligible for a different Medicaid eligibility category
  • Months in which an individual meets a good cause exemption (e.g., disability, hospitalization, birth or death of a household member, severe inclement weather, or family emergency) do not count as a month of non-compliance
faqs.description2:

title: Waiver Extension and Amendment Request Undergoing CMS Review
first_heading: Proposed Changes in the Creating Opportunities for Medicaid Participants to Achieve Self- Sufficiency (COMPASS) Extension

faqs.description:
• Waiver extension and amendment request submitted to CMS on 11/20/2018
  • State transitioning existing Governor’s Access Plan and Addiction and Recovery Treatment Services Delivery System Transformation Demonstration that authorized a limited benefit package for individuals with SMI (population will be covered under expansion group) to demonstration with the features described below

MMC

  • Adults with incomes from 0-138% FPL1
  • Former foster care youth up to age 26

• For individuals with incomes from 100-138% FPL
  • In the form of contributions to the Health and Wellness Account (similar to an HSA; referred to as payments toward the “deductible”)
  • $5/month for individuals with incomes from 100-125% FPL; $10/month for individuals with incomes from 126-138% FPL
  • Individuals who fail to pay monthly contributions within three-month grace period dis-enrolled; may re-enroll upon meeting premium requirement for one month, meeting an exemption, or if income drops below 100% FPL
  • Proposed exempt populations from premiums are the same as those exempt from work/CE requirements

• For individuals with incomes from 100-138% FPL
  • Limited to $5 co-payment for non-emergency use of the ER
  • Co-payments will not be paid point-of-service; State will deduct co-payments from Health and Wellness Account (HSA-like account)

• Individuals who complete at least one healthy behavior (e.g., annual wellness exam, mammogram, tobacco counseling or medication, SUD treatment) during a coverage year may reduce their premiums by 50% for the following coverage year
  • Individuals who have made a minimum required amount of contributions towards their Health and Wellness Account “deductible” ($50 for those from 100-125% FPL and $100 for those from 126-138% FPL) and engage in a healthy behavior will be eligible for a gift card up to the amount of their contributions that can be used for specified medical or health-related services

• Seeks to maintain waiver of the IMD exclusion for enrollees receiving SUD services regardless of length of stay
  • State plans to submit SPAs to offer employment supports as part of the habilitative services benefit (e.g., vocational and job training, subsidies for industry licensure) and a targeted case management benefit to the population subject to work requirements
  • State seeks to provide housing and employment supports to high needs populations; requests waivers to cap number of individuals who would have access to new housing and employment supports benefits (authorized under HCBS waiver authority), limit benefit to managed care delivery system, limit benefit geographically, and limit provided authorized to deliver benefits; HCBS waiver authority limits eligibility for this new housing and employment supports benefit to individuals who have a significant behavioral health or complex medical conditions and who meet one or more risk factors outlined for housing supports (e.g., chronic homelessness, frequent ED or hospitalizations, history of involvement with the criminal justice system) or employment supports (e.g., inability to obtain or maintain employment, more than one instance of inpatient or outpatient SUD treatment in past two years)
• No prompt enrollment requirement for individuals with incomes >100% FPL; coverage begins the first day of month following the first premium payment

• Requests ability to condition Medicaid eligibility for non-disabled adults ages 19-64 on work/CE requirements
  • Individuals subject to requirements must participate in work/CE activities (e.g., employment, job skills training, job search activities, participation in state workforce development program, participation in tribal or migrant workforce program, education, vocational training, volunteering, caregiving for a non-dependent relative or person with a chronic or disabling condition); phase in of hourly requirement: 
    • 3-5 months: 20 hours/month
    • 6-8 months: 40 hours/month
    • 9-11 months: 60 hours/month
    • 12+ months: 80 hours/month
  • Proposed exempt populations include: students; dual eligibles; individuals with blindness or a disability; pregnant women; postpartum women up to six months after delivery; former foster care youth under age 26; primary caregivers of a dependent child under age 19; primary caregivers of an adult dependent or a non-dependent relative with a disability; medically frail individuals; individuals fulfilling SNAP or TANF work requirements; individuals with an acute medical condition that prevents them from meeting work/CE requirements; individuals residing in an institution; individual with a SMI or disabling mental condition; and victims of domestic violence (some exemptions may be time limited)
  • Individuals who fail to comply with work/CE requirements for three consecutive or non-consecutive months in a 12-month period have their benefits suspended unless they meet a good cause exemption (e.g., hospitalization, serious illness, hospitalization or serious illness of an immediate family member, temporary incapacitation, birth or death of a household member, severe inclement weather, family emergency, change in family circumstance, residing in a geographic area with high unemployment, residing in a geographic area where state workforce programs are at capacity or unavailable, medical inability to engage in work/CE on a short-term basis, displacement due to a catastrophic event)
  • Individuals may re-activate suspended coverage at the end of their 12-month coverage year or by meeting requirements for one month, turning age 65, qualifying for another Medicaid eligibility category, or meeting a good cause exemption
  • For enrollees who are not exempt from or are not already meeting work requirements, State will conduct an assessment to identify and connect them to any needed employment supports

faqs.description:
PCCM

  • Nearly all Medicaid enrollees
  • State has not expanded Medicaid and covers parents/caretakers with incomes up to 43% FPL

ESI Premium Assistance

  • Available to individuals with incomes ≤200% FPL who work for a qualifying employer that offers ESI, including:
    • Non-disabled individuals ages 19–64 who work for an employer with ≤250 employees and their non-working spouses
    • Disabled individuals ages 19–64 who are otherwise ineligible for Medicaid because of their income
    • Up to 3,000 full-time college students ages 19–22 with no access to other creditable health insurance options
    • Foster parents ages 19–64 (either full-time or part-time) and their non-working spouses
    • Individuals ages 19–64 working for not-for-profit organizations with ≤500 employees and their non-working spouses
  • Individuals eligible for ESI premium assistance are not otherwise eligible under the State Plan

Limited Coverage Option Administered by Oklahoma Health Care Authority that Covers EHBs (Insure Oklahoma Individual Plan)

  • Available to individuals with incomes ≤100% FPL who are:
    • Non-disabled individuals ages 19–64 who are self-employed or unemployed and their non-working spouses
    • Working disabled individuals ages 19–64 who are otherwise ineligible for Medicaid because of their income
    • Up to 3,000 full-time college students ages 19–22 with no access to other creditable health insurance options
    • Working foster parents ages 19–64 (either full-time or part-time) and their non-working spouses
    • Individuals ages 19–64 working for not-for-profit organizations with ≤500 employee and their non-working spouses
  • Individuals eligible for the Individual Plan are not otherwise eligible under the State Plan

• Premiums charged on a household basis for premium assistance enrollees
  • For individuals enrolled in ESI premium assistance program: Up to 15% of total premium (employer plus employee share), not to exceed 3% of household income
  • For individuals enrolled in the Insure Oklahoma Individual Plan: 20% of age- and gender-based premium band established by state annually, not to exceed 4% of household income; individuals who fail to pay monthly premium within 60-day grace period and do not have a hardship waiver terminated

• State Plan cost sharing for populations that would otherwise be eligible under the State Plan
  • For individuals enrolled in ESI premium assistance program, copayments are as specified by the ESI plan with following limitations:
    • Up to $50 for office visits
    • Up to $500 deductible for pharmacy
    • Up to $3,000 out of pocket maximum for each individual, excluding pharmacy
    • $30 copay for ED visits that do not result in hospitalization
    • Subject to cap of 5% of household income
  • For individuals enrolled in Insure Oklahoma Individual Plan: Cost-sharing subject to maximum permitted Medicaid cost-sharing levels, with exception of $30 ED copay
